table_items.text: MANAGEMENT OF CARDIAC DISEASE IN PREGNANCY

Appendix A: Cardiovascular Physiology and EEG Changes in Pregnancy ............... 33 Appendix B: New York Heart Association classification ............................................. 35 Appendix C: Pregnancy and Cardiac Investigations ........ 3Error! Bookmark not defined. Appendix D: Maternal Risk Assessment ....................................................................... 37 Appendix E: Preliminary Equality Analysis ................................................................... 38
Introduction

Cardiovascular disease encompasses a diverse range of conditions including congenital cardiac disease, ischaemic heart disease, conduction disorders, acquired valve disorders and hypertensive disorders.
Cardiovascular disease complicates less than 1% of pregnancies in the UK. It is a significant cause of maternal mortality in the UK.
Scope
To manage pregnancies complicated by cardiovascular diseases.
To diagnose and treat acute cardiac events during pregnancy.
Equality impact assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer top Appendix E)
Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Obstetric Clinical Lead Consultant and Labour Ward Lead Consultant are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
Congenital heart disease
In many, pregnancy will be well tolerated; risk depends on presence of cardiac failure; certain lesions at particularly high risk and these are usually known about pre-pregnancy.
Pre-pregnancy assessment
5.2.1 Women with suspected cardiac symptoms (i.e. palpitation, shortness of breath, previous cardiac surgery etc.) should be referred for Consultant clinic following the booking appointment.
5.2.2 Women with known medical disorders / cardiac disease should be referred to Maternity Medicine Clinic.

Medical and surgical history: particularly cardiomyopathies, the Marfan syndrome,congenital heart disease, juvenile sudden death, long QT syndrome, and catecholaminergic ventricular tachycardia (VT) or Brugada syndrome,sudden deaths in the family;
Presence of prosthetic material or uncorrected lesions;
Echocardiogram;
Exercise testing (if can only achieve < 70% anticipated workload, drop in blood pressure or de-saturates then higher risk of decompensation during pregnancy);
Cardiology opinion and drug optimisation;
Consider need for anticoagulation.
5.2.3 General management of pregnancy:
Inform and document of increased risk of pregnancy;
Document NYHA (New York Heart Association) status at booking;
Emphasise need for good dental hygiene;
Fetal medicine referral;
Cardiology referral;
Consider need for tertiary centre referral;
Paediatric referral;
VTE risk assessment;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
Plan antenatal care including timing of echocardiograms etc individually;
Fetal echocardiogram;
Multidisciplinary meeting at 32 weeks to decide and document delivery plan:
Vaginal birth vs. Caesarean section;
Analgesia/anaesthesia (early slow incremental epidural);
Length and management of second stage (short and assisted);
Use of oxytocics in PPH prophylaxis (low dose syntocinon infusion probably safest);
Compression sutures at CS rather than oxytocics;
Postpartum plan.
High risk maternal conditions
NYHA III or IV or with severely reduced left ventricular function at high risk Specific conditions at particularly high risk include:
Pulmonary hypertension (PAH)
Range of disorders can lead to pulmonary hypertension:
Idiopathic and inherited pulmonary arterial hypertension;
Lung disease associated (cor pulmonale);
Congenital heart disease (corrected or uncorrected);
Chronic and repeated pulmonary emboli;
As a consequence of left ventricular disease;
Other.
6.2.1 Mean pulmonary arterial pressure of > 25mmHg at rest Pregnancy causes reduced systemic resistance and right ventricular overload even if only moderate PAH.
6.2.2 Mortality
Maternal mortality up to 50% in severe pulmonary hypertension or Eisenmenger's syndrome;

Maternal death occurs in the last trimester of pregnancy and in the first months after delivery because of pulmonary hypertensive crises, pulmonary thrombosis, or refractory right heart failure. This occurs even in patients with little or no disability before or during pregnancy;
Risk factors: general anaesthesia, severity of hypertension, late hospitalisation;
Can occur even if minimal symptoms pre-pregnancy;
Neonatal survival rates of 87-89%.
6.2.3 Management
Aim to maintain circulating volume, avoid systemic hypotension, hypoxia, and acidosis which may precipitate refractory heart failure.
Ideally avoid pregnancy with effective contraception;

Pre-pregnancy optimisation with up-to-date assessment of cardiovascular status should be undertaken by the link Consultant Cardiologist; Fiona Walker at UCLH Hospital; contact details: 02034564511; email Fiona.walker@uclh.nhs.uk. In her absence an opinion could be sought from Dr Gerald Clesham Consultant Consultant Cardiologist Lead Clinician Cardiologist,
Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy / 17022 / 2.0
Page  of

Emailgerald.clesham@meht.nhs.uk  , extension 4232. The midwife undertaking the initial assessment at booking should refer the woman to the Maternal Medicine Clinic. The midwife should email the Consultant for Maternal Medicine with the woman's details;
For women of known cardiac abnormality, referral should be made to
Dr Gamma; who can be contact via bleep number 2395; or via Dr Gamma's
secretary on extension 6727;or from Dr Clesham as detailed above.
Document clearly risks of mortality and offer termination of pregnancy in a cardiac centre;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
Urgent referral to a tertiary centre with full cardiothoracic and critical care facilities available;
Consider continuing pre-existing medication but discuss risks of teratogenicity (but benefits will almost always outweigh risks);
General principles:
Eisenmenger's syndrome
Pulmonary hypertension causing shunting of deoxygenated blood by reversal of pre-existing left to right shunt causing cyanosis
6.3.1 Mortality
Physiological drop in systemic resistance during pregnancy causes worsening of shunt reversal and worsening cyanosis;
Eventually low output cardiac failure results;
Maternal mortality of up to 50% in the peripartum period;
If oxygen saturations < 85%, then live birth unlikely (<12%).
6.3.2 Management
Ideally avoid pregnancy with effective contraception;
Pre-pregnancy optimisation with up-to-date assessment of cardiovascular status by cardiologist;
Document clearly risks of mortality and offer termination of pregnancy in a cardiac centre although significant risks with termination as well;
Refer to a tertiary centre with full cardiothoracic and critical care facilities
immediately;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
6.3.3 General principles:
Maintain circulating volume;
Avoid systemic hypotension;
Avoid hypoxia and acidosis;
Supplemental oxygen if hypoxic;
Consider bed rest;
Judicious use of diuretics to treat symptomatic heart failure whilst avoiding intravascular depletion;
Haematology review:
Frequent clinical review with saturations and FBCs;
Early Caesarean if deterioration or planned admission and elective delivery with incremental regional anaesthesia.
Cyanotic heart disease without pulmonary hypertension
Congenital cyanotic heart disease usually corrected in  childhood. Inoperable or palliative patients may reach child-bearing age.
6.4.1 Maternal complications: 30% of cyanotic pregnant patients:
Heart failure;
Pulmonary thrombus;
Systemic thrombosis;
Supraventricular arrhythmias;
Infective endocarditis.

6.4.2 When the oxygen saturation is 85%, a substantial maternal and fetal mortality risk is expected and pregnancy is contraindicated. If resting oxygen saturation is 85–90% it is advisable to measure it during exercise. If the saturation decreases significantly and early, patients should be advised that pregnancy has a poor prognosis.
6.4.3 Mortality and morbidity
30% chance of complications in pregnancy including:
Heart failure;
Arrhythmias;
Endocarditis;
Thrombosis (very high risk, may be paradoxical).
If oxygen saturations less than 85% then chance of live birth around 12%
6.4.4 Management
Ideally avoid pregnancy with effective contraception;
Pre-pregnancy optimisation with up-to-date assessment of cardiovascular status by cardiologist;
If saturations at rest 85-90% consider exercise testing;

Document clearly risks of mortality and offer termination of pregnancy in a cardiac centre especially if significant exercise desaturation or saturation at rest <85% as low chance of successful pregnancy;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
Refer to a tertiary centre with full cardiothoracic and critical care facilities immediately;
Consider restricted physical activity/bed rest;
Supplemental oxygen;
Haematology review to consider thromboprophylaxis and iron supplementation;
TEDS;
Judicious use of diuretics to treat symptomatic heart failure whilst avoiding intravascular depletion;
Aim for vaginal delivery (usually planned, elective) but early Caesarean section if maternal or fetal condition declines;
Incremental regional anaesthesia may improve outcome.
Severe left ventricular outflow tract obstruction

6.5.1 Subvalvular, valvular (aortic stenosis) or supravalvular obstruction If severe then pregnancy considered contraindicated and lesion should be treated prior to pregnancy. If pregnancy occurs then offer termination of pregnancy.
6.5.2 Subvalvular and supravalvular obstructions: only case reports but management likely similar to aortic stenosis but without option of balloon valvuloplasty. (Refer to aortic stenosis)
Moderate and low risk maternal conditions
If previous successful surgical repair without mechanical heart valve then pregnancy is often well tolerated if:
Exercise tolerance good;
Normal ventricular function;
Functional status good.
7.1.2  General management
Inform and document of increased risk of pregnancy (but risk is often small);
Obstetrician review by the end of 1st trimester;
Document NYHA status;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
Plan antenatal care including timing of echocardiograms etc individually;
Vaginal delivery appropriate in most cases.
Management of specific conditions:
7.2.1 Atrial septal defects

The ASD is the most common defect seen in pregnancy. Pregnancy usually well tolerated if ASD uncomplicated; patients have often had closure prior to pregnancy If Eisenmenger's syndrome or pulmonary hypertension present then refer to the relevant section.
7.2.2 Risks
Refer to the section on Eisenmenger's syndrome or pulmonary hypertension section if these complicate ASD;
If repaired ASD: no extra risk;
If unrepaired ASD: pre-eclampsia and small for gestational age babies may be more frequent;
Paradoxical embolism.
7.2.3 Management
Up to date echocardiogram to note size of defect, residual shunt and pulmonary pressures;
Urgent referral to cardiologist if uncorrected defect, pulmonary hypertension or
worsening clinical symptoms;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
For uncorrected secundum defects, closure can be done during pregnancy via catheter but only if worsening clinical condition;
Small asymptomatic ASDs or PFOs do not need closure
If residual shunt or uncorrected defect: risk of paradoxical embolism
Spontaneous vaginal delivery usually appropriate
7.2.4 Indication for closure:
Patients with symptoms (paradoxic emboli, exercise intolerance, fatigue, heart failure, dysrhythmias);
Pulmonary/systemic shunt flow ratio greater than 2:1 are candidates for closure of the defect.
Ventricular septal defects - pregnancy usually well tolerated if VSD uncomplicated.

7.3.1 Large VSD may be associated with cardiac dilation, pulmonary hypertension and/or Eisenmenger's syndrome; often had closure prior to pregnancy. If Eisenmenger's syndrome or pulmonary hypertension present then see relevant section.
7.3.2 Risks
See section on Eisenmenger's syndrome or pulmonary hypertension section if these complicate VSD;
Corrected VSD with normal LV function have a good prognosis during pregnancy;
Small, perimembranous VSDs without cardiac dilation have a low risk of complications;
Potential higher risk of pre-eclampsia.
7.3.3 Management
Up to date echocardiogram to note size of defect, residual shunt, cardiac dimensions and pulmonary pressures;
Urgent referral to cardiologist if uncorrected defect, pulmonary hypertension or worsening clinical symptoms;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
Spontaneous vaginal delivery usually appropriate.
Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
A small PDA is usually asymptomatic and tolerated well in pregnancy;
Larger PDAs are associated with risks of ventricular overload and pulmonary hypertension similar to ASD and VSD.
Atrioventricular septal defects - pregnancy well tolerated if corrected defect with minimal residual regurgitation and normal ventricular function. Wide spectrum of severity
7.5.1 Risks
See section on Eisenmenger's syndrome or pulmonary hypertension section if these complicate AVSD;
Worsening AV regurgitation during pregnancy;
Cardiac arrhythmias;
Low risk of cardiac failure unless severe regurgitation or impaired ventricular function;
Risk of peripartum cardiac failure related to symptoms and pulmonary artery pressure during pregnancy;
If uncorrected AVSD, risk of paradoxical embolism;
Significant risk of passing on complex congenital heart disease to the baby.
7.5.2 Management
Pre-pregnancy optimisation with up-to-date assessment of cardiovascular status by cardiologist;
Auscultation: ASD: systolic ejection murmur at left sternal border and wide, fixed split second heart sound. VSD: holosystolic thrill and murmur at left sternal border;
PDA: grade 3/6 continuous systolic and diastolic murmur in intraclavicular region (Gibson murmur);

Echocardiogram to evaluate size of defect, severity of shunting, and measure pulmonary artery pressures. If significant AV regurgitation with symptoms or impaired ventricular function then refer to cardiothoracic surgeon for pre- pregnancy surgical correction.
7.5.3 Similarly haemodynamically significant AVSDs should be considered for pre- pregnancy surgical correction

ECG: ASD: partial right bundle branch block, right axis deviation, and sometimes right ventricular hypertrophy. VSD/PDA: usually normal, may show left or right ventricular hypertrophy. Oxygen saturations at booking; 24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
Cardiology follow up each trimester unless moderate/severe AV regurgitation or impaired ventricular function who may need monthly or bimonthly assessment;
If uncorrected defect: risk of paradoxical embolism;
Spontaneous vaginal delivery usually appropriate;
Hypertension, tachycardia, decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance should be avoided as these increase left to right shunt.
Coarctation of the aorta - pregnancy often well tolerated after repair of coarctation and uncorrected coarctation should be considered for pre-pregnancy surgical repair.
7.6.1 Risks

If uncorrected coarctation, residual coarctation after repair, residual hypertension after previous repair or coexisting aortic aneurysm then increased risk of aortic rupture or intracranial haemorrhage during pregnancy and delivery;
Hypertension during pregnancy;
Miscarriage.
7.6.2 Management
Pre-pregnancy optimisation with up-to-date assessment of cardiovascular status by cardiologist;
Up to date echocardiogram to note aortic dimensions and aortic valve function;
Significant (re) coarctation should be considered for pre-pregnancy surgical repair;
Cardiology follow up each trimester;
Close blood pressure monitoring with treatment of hypertension avoiding aggressive lowering in patients with significant residual coarctation to avoid impairing placental perfusion;

If hypertension remains refractory to maximal medical therapy for lowering blood pressure especially if maternal/fetal compromise can consider percutaneous stenting of lesion but higher risk of dissection than outside of pregnancy;
Spontaneous vaginal delivery preferable with epidural anaesthesia especially if hypertensive.
Pulmonary valve stenosis and regurgitation

7.7.3 Pulmonary stenosis usually well tolerated during pregnancy unless severe which can result in arrhythmias and right ventricular failure If severe stenosis consider pre- pregnancy balloon valvuloplasty. Severe pulmonary regurgitation if symptomatic or associated with right ventricular dysfunction should be considered for pre- pregnancy valve replacement.
7.7.4 Risks
Mild and moderate pulmonary stenosis are considered low risk lesions;
Cardiac arrhythmias;
Cardiac failure;
Hypertensive disorders including pre-eclampsia may be increased in women with pulmonary stenosis.
7.7.5 Management
Up to date echocardiogram to note degree of pulmonary stenosis, cardiac dimension, pulmonary pressures including valve gradient pressure and right ventricular function;
Cardiology follow up each trimester;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
If severe pulmonary stenosis then monthly or bimonthly cardiology follow up required;
If severely symptomatic stenosis refractory to medical management and bed rest then consider balloon valvuloplasty;
Vaginal delivery if non-severe stenosis or minimal symptoms. Consider Caesarean section if severe stenosis and NYHA III or IV or cannot be improved with medical treatment or valvuloplasty.
Bicuspid Aortic Valve - commonest cause of congenital aortic stenosis. Most commonly asymptomatic and patient unaware of diagnosis
7.8.1 Risks
Associated with aortic dilation and dissection.
7.8.2 Management
Pre-pregnancy imaging with CT or MRI of ascending aorta with surgical intervention if diameter is > 5cm.

Tetralogy of Fallot - large VSD, pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta and right ventricular hypertrophy. Often repaired surgically in childhood. Uncorrected Tetralogy of Fallot should be repaired pre-pregnancy but in those who have been repaired, pregnancy is usually well tolerated.
7.9.1 Risks
Cardiac complications in up to 12% during pregnancy;
Arrhythmias, cardiac failure, VTE, progressive aortic root dilatation, endocarditis;
Progressive right ventricular dilatation;
Right ventricular dysfunction and significant pulmonary regurgitation are risk factors for cardiovascular complications.
7.9.2 Management
If unrepaired, refer for consideration of repair prior to pregnancy;
If symptomatic with right ventricular dilation due pulmonary regurgitation then refer for consideration of pre-pregnancy valve replacement;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
Cardiology review each trimester;
If severe pulmonary regurgitation, monthly or bimonthly cardiology follow up;
If right ventricular failure develops during pregnancy treat with diuretics and bed rest. Failure to respond then consider transcatheter valve implantation;
Aim for vaginal delivery.
Ebstein's Anomaly

7.10.1 If no cyanosis or heart failure, pregnancy is usually well tolerated. Pregnancy related symptoms depend on degree of tricuspid regurgitation and if severe and symptomatic consideration should be given to tricuspid repair pre-pregnancy. Often associated with ASD and arrhythmias including Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome.
7.10.2 Risks
Life threatening cardiac arrhythmias;
VTE and paradoxical embolism;
Cyanosis and cardiac failure including Eisenmenger's Syndrome;
Premature delivery and intrauterine death.
7.10.3 Management
See Eisenmenger's syndrome section if appropriate;
Up to date echocardiogram to assess degree of ASD, RV function;
Cardiology referral;
VTE risk assessment;
ECG and oxygen saturations at booking;
24 hour tape if suspicion of paroxysmal arrhythmias;
Medical management of even severe tricuspid regurgitation usually effective: cautious diuretics etc;
Aim for vaginal delivery.
Congenital aortic disease

Congenital Aortic Disease includes Marfan's syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Turner's syndrome and bicuspid aortic valve. May also complicate other congenital cardiac defects such as Tetralogy of Fallot.
8.1.1 Risks
Aortic root dilatation and valve dysfunction;
Aortic dissection;
8.1.2 General Management
Discussion of risks prior to pregnancy;
Pre-pregnancy imaging of entire aorta;
Cardiology referral and consider referral to tertiary centre;
If high risk syndrome (e.g. Marfan's or Ehlers-Danlos) consider pre-pregnancy repair of aorta if > 45mm. In lower risk patients consider surgery if > 50mm;
If very small women (e.g. Turner's syndrome) calculate aortic diameter index (root diameter/body surface area). Consider surgery if > 27;
4-12 weekly (depending on actual diameter) echocardiograms and for 6 months post-partum;
Consider beta blockers to reduce risk of dissection;
Fetal growth scans if using beta blockers;
If progressive dilatation prior to viability consider aortic repair with foetus in utero;
If progressive dilatation after viability, consider delivery in cardiothoracic centre by Caesarean section and proceed to aortic repair;
High index of suspicion for acute dissection;
If acute dissection, immediate delivery by Caesarean and proceed to repair in cardiothoracic centre;
Continue beta blockers intra-partum and post-partum if already taking;
Aim to reduce cardiovascular stress during delivery.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition and 80% of those affected have cardiac effects of the disease. Aneurysmal dilatation and dissection of the aorta account for most of the morbidity and mortality associated with the Marfan syndrome. From 60% to 80% of adults with the Marfan syndrome have aortic root dilatation with or without aortic regurgitation. The risk of aortic rupture or dissection during pregnancy is w10% if the aortic root diameter is greater than 4 cm.36 Rupture and dissection can occur even with a normal aortic dimension (<1%
8.2.1 Risks
If normal aortic root diameter: 1% risk of dissection or serious complications during pregnancy;
If diameter > 45mm, discourage pregnancy;
Risk of worsening mitral regurgitation with cardiac failure and arrhythmias especially of pre-pregnancy mitral regurgitation;
Even if aortic root repaired, increased risk of dissection in the rest of the aorta.

Turner's Syndrome - cardiovascular malformations common and include bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation and aortic disease. Dissection can occur without dilatation. Often short stature so calculate aortic diameter index. If more than 27, high risk of dissection, consider prophylactic surgery. Also increased risk of hypertension and pre-eclampsia.
Valve disease

There are a wide variety of causes including congenital abnormalities, rheumatic fever and connective tissue disorders and previous infective endocarditis. In addition to haemodynamic effects, also risk of VTE, endocarditis and arrhythmias to be considered. In general stenotic lesions are more poorly tolerated during pregnancy than regurgitant lesions and left-sided valve lesions worse than right-sided.
Stenotic lesions
Mitral Stenosis - poorly tolerated during pregnancy and often a result of previous rheumatic fever. May be asymptomatic and causes a late diastolic murmur.
10.1.1 Risks
Risk of decompensation and development of cardiac failure;
A valve area of < 1.5cm2 (moderate or severe MS) often causes heart failure even if previously asymptomatic;
Highest risk of decompensation during 2nd and 3rd trimester;
Risk of developing atrial fibrillation and acute pulmonary oedema;
Prematurity rates of 20-30%, IUGR and stillbirth rate of 1-3%.
10.1.2 Management
If known moderate or severe MS (even if asymptomatic) counsel against pregnancy and consider pre-pregnancy valve repair
Up to date echocardiogram to assess mitral valve anatomy, valve area, left ventricular function, pulmonary artery pressure
ECG at booking
VTE risk assessment
Low threshold for investigation of suspected paroxysmal arrhythmias
Cardiology referral and if moderate or severe MS refer to tertiary centre
Monthly or even twice-monthly follow-up clinically and echocardiographically.
In mild MS, see every trimester and just prior to delivery
If symptoms or pulmonary hypertension develop then advise to rest and start β1-selective blocker
Cautious use of diuretics
Anticoagulate if atrial arrhythmias, atrial thrombosis, previous thrombosis, left atrial dilatation or congestive cardiac failure

If NYHA III/IV or persistent pulmonary arterial pressure of > 50mmHg despite optimal medical treatment, consider percutaneous mitral valve commissurotomy after  weeks gestation with abdominal lead shielding. Open heart surgery if maternal life in danger.
Mild MS or uncomplicated moderate/severe (NYHA class I/II with normal pulmonary pressures) consider vaginal delivery
Caesarean section if moderate/severe with NYHA class III/IV or refractory pulmonary hypertension

Aortic Stenosis - main cause is congenitally bicuspid valve. Often asymptomatic even if severe AS. Consider diagnosis if exercise induced chest pain, dyspnoea or syncope. Causes an ejection systolic murmur but may be difficult to differentiate from normal pregnancy flow murmur. Pregnancy often well tolerated.
10.2.1 Risks
Risk of heart failure around 10% if severe AS;
Risk of arrhythmias around 3-25% in severe AS;
Mortality rare;
Consider risk of root dilatation and dissection in bicuspid valve;
Premature labour;
Hypertensive disorders;
IUGR.
10.2.2 Management
Exercise testing pre-pregnancy if asymptomatic to confirm asymptomatic;
If symptomatic pre-pregnancy, evidence of rapid progression, severe AS, pathological exercise test or LV dysfunction refer for consideration of valve repair and advise to defer pregnancy;
If bicuspid valve, image aortic root to check diameter;
Up to date echocardiogram to assess degree of AS, valve area, left ventricular function;
If asymptomatic, even if severe AS, providing exercise test is normal and LV hypertrophy is not severe, no need to discourage pregnancy;
Refer to cardiology;
Regular follow-up: monthly or twice monthly cardiac review with echocardiography if severe or progressive disease;
If symptoms develop during pregnancy:
In severe AS advise delivery by Caesarean under general anaesthesia;
If non-severe, vaginal delivery recommended avoiding a decrease in
peripheral vascular resistance.
Regurgitant lesions
Aortic and Mitral Regurgitation may be due to congenital, rheumatic or d

egenerative disease, previous valve surgery or endocarditis. Rarely, antiphospholipid syndrome may cause acute regurgitation during pregnancy. Lower risk during pregnancy than stenotic lesions as reduced afterload reduces the regurgitated volume. Severe regurgitation with LV dysfunction or acute onset regurgitation is poorly tolerated.
11.1.1 Risks
If severe regurgitation or LV dysfunction, high risk of developing heart failure;
Commonly arrhythmias, even if asymptomatic otherwise;
Persistent worsening if regurgitation.
11.1.2 Management
Pre-pregnancy echocardiogram to assess cardiac size, LV function, valve anatomy etc;
Pre-pregnancy exercise test;
Pre-pregnancy imaging of aortic root diameter;
If severe regurgitation with symptoms or LV dysfunction/dilatation, refer for pre-pregnancy surgical repair;
Refer to cardiology;
If mild/moderate, to see cardiologist at lease every trimester, more often if severe;
Cautious use of diuretics in fluid overload;
If acute severe regurgitation with medically resistant heart failure, may need urgent surgical repair. Aim to deliver the foetus prior to proceeding to repair if possible;
Aim for vaginal delivery with epidural anaesthesia and shortened second stage.

Tricuspid Regurgitation - usually functional i.e. due to ventricular dilatation for another reason. Only impacts on maternal risk if severe enough to be symptomatic or associated with RV dysfunction. Can lead to arrhythmias when associated with other congenital cardiac disease. Even when severe enough to cause symptoms, can usually be managed medically during pregnancy however if surgically repairing left sided lesions then can consider tricuspid repair at the same time. Aim for vaginal delivery.
Prosthetic heart valves

Bioprosthetic valves - if bioprosthetic valve in situ pregnancy is usually well tolerated and maternal risk is related to function of the valve. Low risk if minimal dysfunction and no ventricular dysfunction. See sections on native valve dysfunction if issues with bioprosthetic valve.

Mechanical valves - well-functioning mechanical valves result in minimal haemodynamic risk during pregnancy and from this point of view pregnancy is well tolerated. Maternal and fetal risk is increased however because of the need for anticoagulation.
12.2.1 Risks
Increased risk of valve thrombosis during pregnancy (3.9% if oral anticoagulants used throughout pregnancy, 33% if unfractionated heparin used throughout);
Maternal mortality rate of up to 15% if unfractionated heparins used throughout pregnancy. 2% if oral anticoagulants used. Death usually secondary to valve thrombosis;
Less evidence for LMWH prophylaxis. Risk is lowered if LMWH dosed according to anti-factor Xa activity even so a thrombosis rate of 9% reported in 1 study;
All anticoagulant regimes increase risk of miscarriage, haemorrhage, preterm birth and foetal demise;

Oral anticoagulants throughout pregnancy have lowest maternal risk. Risk of warfarin induced embryopathy is dose related: 2.6% if dose < 5mg/day and 8% if > 5mg/day. Substituting UFH or LMWH (unlicensed use, LMWH probably better than UFH) for weeks 6-12 greatly reduce this risk. Warfarin use outside the 1st trimester associated with low risk of minor CNS abnormalities. Vaginal delivery on warfarin contraindicated because of risk of intracranial haemorrhage;
Most thrombolytics do not cross the placenta but if used to treat valve thrombosis there is a 10% chance of embolisation and a risk of subplacental bleeding.
12.2.2 Management
Obtain previous notes regarding indication for replacement, type of valve implanted and position as well as follow-up since procedure;
Previous history of valve thrombosis, previous anticoagulant use and problems including compliance documented;
Document current symptoms, obtain echocardiography to assess prosthesis function ideally pre-pregnancy and refer if any concerns
Document discussion with parents:
INR should be monitored at least weekly and if becomes subtherapeutic, cover with enoxaparin should be given;

Baseline platelet count should be done in all patients starting heparin. This should be repeated every 4 days for the first 2 weeks and then fortnightly to monitor for heparin induced thrombocytopaenia;
Referral to fetal medicine centre if using warfarin in the 1st trimester;
A comprehensive plan should be documented that has been agreed by consultant obstetrician and haematologist regarding anticoagulation management during pregnancy, delivery and post-partum;
Monthly echocardiograms to exclude valve thrombosis;
Patients with antepartum haemorrhage or who develop other antenatal complications due to or impacting upon anticoagulation should be discussed with the haematology consultant on call;

Planned vaginal delivery with prior switch to heparin based anticoagulation. If very high risk can consider elective Caesarean to minimise time without oral anticoagulants. If labour occurs whilst still on oral anticoagulants, delivery should be by Caesarean section;
There should be a low threshold for investigation of valve thrombosis:
Ischaemic heart disease and acute coronary syndrome
This is rare in this population however numbers are increasing; associated with
high morbidity and mortality and diagnosis is often delayed. Maybe due to thrombosis, vasospasm of the coronary arteries or coronary artery dissection all of which are more common during pregnancy.
Acute coronary syndrome
Risk factors include:
Smoking;
Hypertension;
Advanced maternal age;
Hyperlipidaemia;
Diabetes Mellitus;
Family history;
Pre-eclampsia;
Sepsis;
Severe haemorrhage;
Ergometrine use (coronary artery vasospasm);
14.1.1 Highest risk time is peripartum.
14.1.2 5-10% maternal mortality.
14.1.3 Long-term mortality and morbidity depends on size of infarct and persistence of risk factors.
14.1.4 ACS prior to delivery may result in fetal demise or preterm labour.
Symptoms
Acute onset chest pain (may be atypical);
Dyspnoea;
Collapse.

14.2.1 ACS, PE and aortic dissection must be considered in all patients who complain of chest pain. The diagnosis is made by considering the history, ECG changes and use of cardiac enzymes (troponin).
Management
Summon help;
ABC approach to stabilise patient;
15L O2 by non-rebreather;
IV access and bloods for FBC, U+E, LFTs, INR and Troponin;
Blood sugar;
ECG.
Morphine 5-10mg IV titrated to pain;
Metoclopramide 10mg IV;
Aspirin 300mg PO if post-partum, 150mg-300mg if antepartum (limited evidence on risks);
Clopidogrel 600mg PO if post-partum, NOT if antepartum;
GTN 2 puffs sublingually;
1:1 nursing;
Consider urgent bedside echocardiogram to check for wall motion abnormalities;
Consider CXR and ABG if suspicion of PE or dissection;
Only when stable assess foetal well-being;
If haemodynamically unstable request ITU review.
STEMI
Priority is transfer to a centre with angiographic and PCI facilities. Discuss with on-call cardiologist at PCI centre: including need for GTN infusion, LMWH or beta-blockers prior to transfer;
If being transferred, discuss with on-call obstetric team at receiving hospital
If life-threatening ACS and unstable for transfer then consider thrombolysis and discussion with consultant haematologist.
NSTEMI
Discuss all cases of suspected ACS with cardiologist on-call at PCI centre as angiography will also elucidate coronary artery dissection;
GTN infusion 50mg/50ml normal saline, 2-10ml/hr titrated to pain and keeping systolic BP > 100;
Anticoagulation
Consider cardioselective beta-blocker especially if tachycardic or hypertensive. e.g. metoprolol 50mg PO TDS;
Consider ACE-I and statins if postpartum;
Repeat troponin at 12hours after onset of chest pain;
Continuous ECG monitoring to look for evolving changes;
If chest pain resolves and 12 hour troponin negative, medical review prior to discharge;
Aim for vaginal delivery.
Cardiomyopathies
Cardiomyopathies are a diverse range of conditions, uncommon but potentially very serious during pregnancy.
15.1.1 Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) - 1:300-1:4000 pregnancies
15.1.2 Risk factors:
Multiparity;
Multiple pregnancy;
Family history;
Smoking;
Diabetes;
Hypertension and pre-eclampsia;
Malnutrition;
Extremes of maternal age;
Prolonged use of beta agonists;

15.1.3 Idiopathic cardiomyopathy of systolic dysfunction presenting with heart failure towards end of pregnancy or in the months following delivery. Diagnosis of exclusion. May not have dilatation but usually ejection fraction < 45%.
15.1.4 May present with acute or subacute heart failure, arrhythmia or sudden cardiac death. 25% will be hypertensive so may be confused with pre-eclampsia.
15.1.5 Roughly 50% will spontaneously recover unlike other causes of heart failure
Acute heart failure
15.2.1 Signs and symptoms of heart failure
Worsening dyspnoea;
Orthopnoea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea;
Palpitations;
Tiredness/lethargy;
Peripheral oedema;
Upper abdominal discomfort;
Productive cough (frothy sputum, may be blood stained).
15.2.2 Acute heart failure management
Seek help;
ABC approach
Sit-up
Oxygen 15L by mask
IV access and bloods for FBC, U+E, LFTs, INR, Troponin and Thyroid profile
5-10mg IV morphine, 10mg metoclopramide IV
puffs GTN S/L followed by IV infusion of 50mg in 50ml Normal saline, 2- 10mg/hr, titrate to symptoms, maintain systolic BP > 100mmHg
Frusemide 40-80mg IV
ECG and continuous monitoring
CXR and ABG
Catheter and output chart
Urgent echocardiography (will help exclude massive PE)
If patient unable to maintain BP or evidence of end-organ hypoperfusion then liaise with ITU regarding need for inotropes
If inotrope dependent discuss with cardiothoracic centre as may benefit
from transfer, intra-aortic balloon, left ventricular-assist device or even transplantation
15.2.3 Urgent delivery by Caesarean section with combined spinal and epidural anaesthesia may need to be considered if remains in cardiac failure with haemodynamic instability.
Chronic heart failure
Joint obstetric/cardiac antenatal care;
ECG at booking;
Echocardiogram at booking;
See obstetrician/cardiologist weekly;
Consider regular weights, growth scans;
Anticoagulate according to risk of bleeding (high risk of VTE);
ACEI and ARBs contraindicated during pregnancy. Enalapril can be used if postpartum, safe in breastfeeding;
Hydralazine/nitrates can be considered for afterload reduction if unable to use ACEI;
Beta1-selective blockers for all patients with cardiac failure if tolerated. Metoprolol 1st line, avoid atenolol. Advise paediatricians if used antenatally;
Cautious use of diuretics if pulmonary oedema;
Avoid aldosterone anatagonists during pregnancy but can be used post- partum;
Consider need for dual chamber pacemaker;
Aim for vaginal delivery if possible but with close monitoring, preferably epidural anaesthesia;
Consider bromocriptine postnatally: some evidence it increases ejection fraction and prevention of lactation (high metabolic demands and fluid shifts) may be beneficial;
If using ACEI postnatally monitor baby weight for 1st 4 weeks as a surrogate for renal function;
Cardiology follow-up;
Subsequent pregnancies have 50% recurrence risk: women should be counselled about this. If ejection fraction has not normalised then counsel against future pregnancy. Advise on contraception.

Dilated cardiomyopathy - symptoms of heart failure with ventricular dilatation on echocardiogram. LV systolic dysfunction. May be present pre-pregnancy or becomes symptomatic during 1st or 2nd trimester. Often family history. Important to try and differentiate from peripartum cardiomyopathy as PPCM has a 50% chance of recovery postnatally. May deteriorate dramatically during pregnancy. Important to consider other causes of cardiomyopathy such as infiltrative, toxic, hypertensive or ischaemic.
15.4.1 Risks
Risk of dramatic deterioration;
LV ejection fraction (LVEF) of < 40% signifies high risk and should be managed in a cardiac centre;
If LVEF < 20% very high mortality rate and termination of pregnancy should be discussed.
15.4.2 Management
As for PPCM;
Higher risk of atrial arrhythmias so low threshold for investigating suspected arrhythmias and for anticoagulation;
Lower threshold for recourse to LVAD or transplantation than in PPCM as less likely to recover function spontaneously.

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy - commonest genetic cardiac disease. Frequently diagnosed for first time during pregnancy. Diastolic dysfunction unlike PPCM and DCM. Symptoms are those of heart failure, exercise syncope due to outflow tract obstruction (fixed cardiac output) or arrhythmias. Pregnancy usually well tolerated but higher risk if symptomatic pre-pregnancy and significant outflow tract obstruction.
15.5.1 Risks
Sudden cardiac death from ventricular arrhythmias;
Progressive heart failure;
If symptomatic pre-pregnancy or significant outflow tract obstruction should be managed at tertiary centre.
15.5.2 Management

Low threshold for beta blockers. More than mild outflow obstruction or ventricular hypertrophy of more than 15mm warrants treatment. In addition beta blockers are anti-arrhythmic against ventricular arrhythmias and rate control atrial fibrillation;
Cardioversion for persistent atrial arrhythmias as these patients are dependent on atrial function to distend stiff ventricle adequately;
Anticoagulation especially if atrial arrhythmias;
Investigate syncope or palpitations urgently as risk of sudden cardiac death. Discuss with cardiology regarding an implantable cardio-defibrillator
Otherwise management as for PPCM;
If low risk consider spontaneous labour and vaginal delivery;
If severe outflow obstruction extreme caution with anaesthesia likely to vasodilate (regional anaesthesia may be contraindicated);
Cautious IV fluids as fluid overload very poorly tolerated;
Slow infusion Syntocinon only as can cause hypotension, arrhythmias and tachycardias.
Arrhythmias

Premature extra beats and sustained tachyarrhythmias more frequent in pregnancy. Pre-existing paroxysmal SVT may become more frequent in pregnancy. Concerns about safety of most anti-arrhythmic drugs in pregnancy so ideally pre-prgenancy catheter ablation should be done if possible.
Arrhythmias in structural heart disease

Supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias occur in around 5% of those with congenital heart disease during pregnancy. Sustained tachyarrhythmias are often poorly tolerated and can cause foetal hypoperfusion in those with structural heart disease. Therefore DC Cardioversion is the treatment of choice to return to sinus rhythm. Digoxin can be used to control ventricular rate as can beta-blockers or class 1 anti-arrhythmics but caution if ventricular impairment. Amiodarone may be used but at lowest possible dose and only when other treatment has failed.
Supraventricular tachycardia - may occur for the first time in pregnancy or pregnancy may exacerbate. Encompasses AV nodal re-entry tachycardia and AV re-entry tachycardia.
17.2.1 Symptoms
Palpitations;
Shortness of breath;
Collapse;
Chest pain.
17.2.2 Management:
ABC approach;
Oxygen 15L by mask;
IV access and bloods including electrolytes sent;
12 lead ECG and cardiac monitor;
Refer to on-call medical team;
If haemodynamically unstable, consider (synchronized) DC cardioversion;
Vagal manoeuvres;
If vagal manoeuvres fail:
If adenosine fails:
Refractory SVT can consider DC cardioversion with fetal monitoring (small risk of fetal arrhythmia)
Once sinus rhythm restored repeat ECG
Cardiology review
If multiple episodes or associated with haemodynamic compromise consider prophylaxis:
If evidence of pre-excitation on ECG then not for AV node blocking drugs (e.g. beta blockers or calcium channel blockers)
Electrophysiology studies should be deferred until after pregnancy unless symptoms otherwise intractable

Atrial flutter and fibrillation - very rare in pregnancy unless associated hyperthyroidism or structural heart disease. If associated with rapid ventricular response may be haemodynamic instability and placental insufficiency. Usually aim for rhythm control rather than rate control.
17.3.1 Management
ABC approach
IV access and bloods including electrolytes and TFTs sent
12 lead ECG and cardiac monitor
Refer to on-call medical team
If haemodynamically unstable:
If haemodynamically stable, definite onset with  hours and no other VTE risk
factors:
IV Flecainide: 2 mg/kg over 10–30 minutes; max. 150 mg, with ECG monitoring:
If haemodynamically stable, onset more than 48 hours ago or unsure:
If chronic or refractory AF:
17.3.2 Anticoagulation is usually with weight adjusted therapeutic enoxaparin but warfarin may be used after 1st trimester until last month of pregnancy if desired.
17.2.2 If frequent paroxysms of AF, prophylaxis with sotalol or flecainide may be tried.
Ventricular tachycardia

17.4.1 Life-threatening and rare. In healthy patients commonest cause is idiopathic right ventricular outflow tract tachycardia. These patients should be referred to a cardiologist for consideration of beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker prophylaxis or catheter ablation.
17.4.2 If structural heart disease then risk of sudden cardiac death in mother. May be first presentation of peripartum cardiomyopathy.
17.4.3 Management
ABC approach;
IV access and bloods including electrolytes and TFTs sent;
12 lead ECG and cardiac monitor;
Refer to on-call medical team;
If haemodynamically unstable:
If haemodynamically stable consider:
IV sotalol;
IV amiodarone;
Prophylaxis with Metoprolol should be considered;
If beta blocker resistant consider amiodarone or ICD prophylaxis.
Congenital long QT syndrome
Women with Congenital Long QT Syndrome are at increased risk of cardiac arrest postpartum compared to pregnancy and pre-conception. Consider prophylaxis with antenatal and postnatal beta blocker.
Infective endocarditis
Infective Endocarditis is rare during pregnancy but extremely serious maternal mortality around 33% from acute cardiac failure and systemic embolization. Fetal mortality around 29%.
Risk factors:
Known valve or congenital heart disease;
Prosthetic heart valve or patch;
IV drug use;
Previous endocarditis.
Signs and Symptoms:
New regurgitant murmur;
Pyrexia of unknown origin;
Systemic embolic phenomena;
Acute or sub-acute cardiac failure;
Vasculitic phenomena: Roth spots, splinter haemorrhages, haematuria.
Diagnosis and Management
Low index of suspicion in patient with risk factors;
Thorough cardiovascular and respiratory examination;
FBC, renal and liver profile, CRP;
Urine dipstick and microscopy;
Refer to on-call medical team;
Blood cultures (3 sets from 3 different locations and 3 different times under strict asepsis);
IV antibiotics in consultation with microbiology consultant only after blood cultures have been sent;
Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE);
If TTE negative but high index of suspicion consider trans-oesophageal echocardiogram in consultation with medical team;
Ongoing management likely to be guided by medical team;
Consider early referral to cardiothoracic surgeon.
Prophylaxis:
Only for those patients at highest risk undergoing high risk procedures;
High risk procedures include invasive dental work and procedures elsewhere in the body in the presence of known infection e.g. incision and drainage of an abscess;
Not during delivery;
Encourage good dental hygiene.
Training requirements
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Guideline Management

20.3.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Infection Prevention

All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection control by ensuring that they wash their hands before and after each procedure and when taking samples of blood for investigation to use the Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT).
Professional midwifery advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Monitoring and audit
Completed adult resuscitation checklists will be collected and archived on a monthly basis to assess overall compliance each month.

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group and appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
References
RCOG. Cardiac Disease and Pregnancy. Good Practice No.13. Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

Regita-Zagrosek V et al. European Society of Cardiology Guidelines on the Management of Cardiovascular Diseases During Pregnancy: The Task Force on the Management of Cardiovascular Diseases During Pregnancy of the European Society of Cardiology. Eur Heart J 2011; 32:3147-3197

Habib G et al. Guideline on the Prevention, Diagnosis, and Treatment of Infective Endocarditis (new version 2009): The Task Force on the Prevention, Diagnosis, and Treatment of Infective Endocarditis of the European Society of Cardiology. Eur Heart J 2009; 30: 2369-2413

Keeling D, Davidson S, Watson H. The Management of Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopaenia: The Haemostasis and Thrombosis Task Force of the British Standards in Haematology. British Society for Haematology 2006 133: 259-269

Hamm C et al. ESC Guidelines for the Management of Acute Coronary Syndromes in Patients Presenting Without Persistent ST-Segment Elevation: The Task Force for the management of acute coronary syndromes (ACS) in patients presenting without persistent ST-segment elevation of the European Society of Cardiology (ESC). Eur Heart J 2011; 32:2999–3054

Van de Werf et al. Management of acute myocardial infarction in patients presenting with persistent ST-segment elevation: The Task Force on the management of ST- segment elevation acute myocardial infarction of the European Society of Cardiology. Eur Heart J 2008; 29: 2909–2945

Task Force on the Management of Cardiovascular Diseases During Pregnancy of the European Society of Cardiology. Expert consensus document on management of cardiovascular diseases during pregnancy. Eur Heart J 2003; 24(8):761–81.)
ESC Guidelines on the management of cardiovascular diseases during pregnancy European Heart Journal (2011) 32, 3147–3197 doi:10.1093/eurheartj/ehr218
Appendix A: Cardiovascular Physiology and ECG Changes in Pregnancy
Expected physiologic changes occurring the antepartum, intrapartum, and postpartum Periods
Antepartum:
Blood volume increases by 20% to 50%
In nonpregnant women total blood volume is w60 to  mL/kg
Systemic vascular resistance decreases by 20%
Accounts for most of the reduction in blood pressure (BP)
Accommodates increase in circulating volume without increase in BP
BP (taken in sitting position)
BP greater than or equal to 140/90 mm Hg abnormal at any time in gestation
BP decreases to lowest point at 28 weeks gestation
After  weeks gestation, BP increases to non-pregnant level by term
Mean arterial pressure unchanged
Heart rate increases by 10 to 15 beats per minute (bpm)
Stroke volume increases by 30%
Cardiac output (CO) increases by 30% to 50%
CO = heart rate X stroke volume
Most of the increase is from stroke volume.
Half of the expected increase occurs by 8 weeks gestation
Peaks end of second trimester, sustained to term.
6 L/min by term Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (preload to left heart) unchanged
Central venous pressure (preload to right heart) unchanged
Pulmonary vascular resistance decreases 30% Hypercoagulable state
Increased fibrinogen.
Platelets unchanged.
Dilutional anaemia despite 30% increase in red cell mass
Intrapartum:
During a contraction:
300 to 500 mL of blood enters circulation.
Heart rate increases.
CO increases by 30%.
BP increases by  to  mm Hg.
Supine position may decrease CO by 20% Postpartum:
Postpartum diuresis between days 2 and 5
CO increases by 50% in the immediate postpartum period
Stroke volume increases 60% in the immediate postpartum period
Reflex bradycardia occurs (15%)
These changes persist for 2 weeks after delivery
Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy
These changes persists for two weeks
Most will have a normal ECG Changes include:
Left axis deviation common
Transient ST and T wave changes (“sagging”)
Q wave and T wave inversion in III
Inverted T waves in V1, V2 and sometime V3
May mimic LVH
Slight sinus tachycardia
Appendix B: New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification

table_items.text: No symptoms at rest or normal physical activity (e.g. walking, climbing stairs)
Mild symptoms (shortness of breath or chest pain) and slight limitation to normal physical activity
Marked limitation to physical activity due to symptoms even during less than normal activity (e.g. walking 10m). Comfortable only at rest
Severe limitations and symptoms at rest. Often bedbound

data.text: Appendix C: Pregnancy and cardiac investigations
ECG: safe in pregnancy. Physiological changes as in appendix

Echocardiography: safe in pregnancy. Useful at looking at anatomy and function of heart including during suspected myocardial infarction as wall motion abnormalities are one of the first features to develop

Trans-oesophageal echocardiography: used to examine complex congenital lesions and in suspected infective endocarditis to look for vegetations. Relatively safe in pregnancy: increased risk of aspiration of stomach contents. If sedation used then need fetal monitoring.

Exercise testing: Ideally done pre-pregnancy to check blood pressure response, chronotropic response and oxygen saturations. May also be used to assess for ischaemic heart disease. If done in pregnancy then aim to reach 80% predicted maximal heart rate. Can be done with semi-recumbent cycling. No evidence of harm.
Stress Echocardiography: can be done with exercise as the stressor but dobutamine should be avoided.
Chest X-ray: useful to assess cardiac size and presence of pulmonary oedema. May also show aortic dilatation; relatively safe, shield abdomen.
MRI: has a small role to play in diagnosing cardiac disease but may be useful to look at aortic pathology. No evidence of harm but avoid gadolinium contrast.

CT chest: small role to play in investigation of CVD during pregnancy with exception of CTPA in the investigation pulmonary embolism. May be around 30x radiation dose of chest x-ray but still likely unlikely to cause harm to foetus.
Nuclear scintigraphy: avoid during pregnancy due to radiation dose

Coronary angiography: May be life saving in acute coronary syndromes and elucidates coronary vasospasm from thrombosis. 150x radiation dose of chest x-ray but absolute risks to foetus still very small. Abdomen should be shielded but can be done if benefits outweigh risks.
Electrophysiology and ablation: ideally done pre-pregnancy and should only be done if arrhythmias uncontrolled with optimal medical therapy. Fetal radiation dose may be 300x that of a chest x-ray.
Appendix D: Maternal risk assessment
The risk to maternal health from continuing pregnancy should be considered, discussed and documented.
Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy / 17022 / 2.0

Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy / 17022 / 2.0
